bibl.title: Letter from T.H.D. Griffitts to Henry Rose Carter, June 12, 1923

div1.p: Griffitts writes that he has been inspecting ponds and implementing measures to curtail mosquito breeding.

div1.head: Letter from T.H.D. Griffitts to Henry Rose Carter, June 12, 1923
div1.opener:
N. M. C. .Im. W
Griffitts.
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
Montgomery, Ala.,
519 Dexter Ave.,
6/12/23.
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I came up from Dothan
yesterday and leave this afternoon
for Mitchell Reservoir Ave
simply checking up this first
summer on this large pond
which, as you know, was
previously prepared more or
less "according to specifications.
There is little resident population left
in a mile zone, so the check
will have to be more of
larvae and adults than of
malaria.

You have noted, I suppose,
that I have raised a question
as to the value of ringing
pine trees. Of course, ringing
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
2
is relatively inexpensive, but
under some conditions if
the gross falling of tags
bark, limbs and bodies do
more damage than the “patter”
of a few from the green tree, it
may be best to leave them, or
even a better investment to fell
them outright and burn the
tops. We know the bad re-
sults from pine bark on
a pond - it floats for a long
time unless washed ashore.

What has been your obser-
vation on the degree of current
toward the head of backwater
on clearance of flotage and
prevention of algal growth?

OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE

TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE

I have noticed on the Golden
Bridge pond (the bad Houston
County pond), where current is
perceptible, there is (or was at two
visits) little flotage on the body
and an absence of algae
On the other portions of the
pond a great amount of
algae and small flotage.
Good road dust is scarce
and I have found dry, wood
ashes the best vehicle for
Paris green - used 1 p. g. to 150 ashes.
It practically all floats, spreads
well and knocks the larvae.
We keep log heaps burning
and have widely covered
half barrels with locks at
convenient points on shore
for stations. So far there
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
4
in practically no A. q. house and
stable infestation, although
A. q. were hatched from the pond
Apr. 29, However, during
May, it rained almost daily.

Beginning next week, Dr. Welch
is sending me a medical
student to see that the people
get “standard” treatment.

If my work on this pond
is a success this season, I
shall refuse to get despondent
about any pond.

I am very anxious about the
Southern P. Co. matter.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, T.H.D. Griffitts (Montgomery address till
16th; then Gen. Delivery,
Dothan, Ala.)
